dt: {bc}to drive danger or attack away from
{bc}to maintain or support in the face of argument or hostile criticism
{bc}to prove (something, such as a doctoral thesis or {d_link|dissertation|dissertation}) valid by answering questions in an oral exam
{bc}to attempt to prevent an opponent from scoring at

dt.t: which God {wi}defend{/wi} that I should wring from him
hired a lawyer to {wi}defend{/wi} their son

dt: {bc}to deny or oppose the right of a {d_link|plaintiff|plaintiff} in regard to (a suit or a wrong charged) {bc}{sx|contest||}
{bc}to retain or seek to retain (something, such as a title or position) against a challenge in a contest
{bc}to take action against attack or challenge

dt.t: playing deep to {wi}defend{/wi} against a pass

pt: {sc}defend{/sc} {sc}protect{/sc} {sc}shield{/sc} {sc}guard{/sc} {sc}safeguard{/sc} mean to keep secure from danger or against attack. {sc}defend{/sc} denotes warding off actual or threatened attack.
{sc}protect{/sc} implies the use of something (such as a covering) as a bar to the admission or impact of what may attack or injure.

pt.t: a hard hat to {it}protect{/it} your head

pt: {sc}shield{/sc} suggests protective intervention in imminent danger or actual attack.

pt.t: {it}shielded{/it} her eyes from the sun with her hand

pt: {sc}guard{/sc} implies protecting with vigilance and force against expected danger.
{sc}safeguard{/sc} implies taking precautionary protective measures against merely possible danger.

et: Middle English {it}defenden,{/it} borrowed from Anglo-French & Latin; Anglo-French {it}defendre, defender,{/it} going back to Latin {it}dēfendere{/it} "to ward off, fend off, repel danger from, protect," from {it}dē-{/it} {et_link|de-|de-} + {it}-fendere,{/it} presumably, "to strike, hit" (unattested without prefixes), going back to Indo-European {it}*g{sup}w{/sup}hen-d{sup}h{/sup}-,{/it} extended determinate form of {it}*g{sup}wh{/sup}en-, *g{sup}wh{/sup}n-{/it} "strike, kill," whence Hittite {it}kuenzi{/it} "(s/he) kills," {it}kunanzi{/it} "(they) kill," Sanskrit {it}hánti{/it} "(s/he) strikes, kills," {it}ghnánti{/it} "(they) strike, kill," Greek {it}theínein{/it} "to strike," {it}épethnon{/it} "(I) killed," Old Irish {it}gonaid{/it} "(s/he) pierces, wounds, kills," Welsh {it}gwan-{/it} "stab, pierce," Lithuanian {it}genù, giñti{/it} "to drive (cattle, etc.)," Old Church Slavic {it}ženǫ, gŭnati{/it} "to drive, chase out, expel"; also, from nominal derivative {it}*g{sup}wh{/sup}on-,{/it} Greek {it}phónos{/it} "bloodshed, murder," and from {it}*g{sup}wh{/sup}ń̥-tih{inf}2{/inf},{/it} Germanic {it}*gunþī, *gunþjō,{/it} whence Old English {it}gūþ{/it} "battle, combat," Old Saxon {it}gūđea,{/it} Old High German {it}gund-,{/it} Old Norse {it}gunnr, guðr{/it}
shortdef: to drive danger or attack away from
to maintain or support in the face of argument or hostile criticism
to prove (something, such as a doctoral thesis or dissertation) valid by answering questions in an oral exam
